content.body: TabAtkins: To test support for specific counter-style names of CSS's `list-style-type` property, I'm thinking that you'd need a visual reference test (since it's supposed to use "decimal" without computing to "decimal" for unrecognized values https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-counter-styles-3/#typedef-counter-style). Does that sound right to you?
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: To test support for specific counter-style names of CSS's list-style-type property, I'm thinking that you'd need a visual reference test (since it's supposed to use "decimal" without computing to "decimal" for unrecognized values https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-counter-styles-3/#typedef-counter-style). Does that sound right to you?

Does that sound right to you?

content.body: I have a reliable test using @counter-style, but that's of limited use since Safari hasn't implemented @counter-style yet
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I have a reliable test using @counter-style, but that's of limited use since Safari hasn't implemented @counter-style yet

content.body: But actually, if it's the implementation of @counter-style that causes `CSS.supports` to return `true` for all values, then maybe I can just combine those heuristics in one test
